question: What is Selenium?
answer: Definition: Selenium is an open-source automated testing framework used for web application testing across multiple browsers. Key Points for Interview: • Free & Open Source - No licensing costs • Multi-Browser Support - Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge • Multi-Language Support - Java, Python, C#, JavaScript, Ruby • Cross-Platform - Windows, macOS, Linux Components: 1. Selenium WebDriver - Core automation API 2. Selenium IDE - Record & playback tool 3. Selenium Grid - Parallel/distributed execution Sample Answer: "Selenium is an open-source automation framework for testing web applications. It supports multiple browsers like Chrome and Firefox, and multiple programming languages like Java and Python. The main components are WebDriver for browser automation, IDE for recording tests, and Grid for parallel execution."

question: What are Selenium components?
answer:
• Selenium WebDriver - browser automation
• Selenium IDE - record & playback
• Selenium Grid - parallel execution

question: Difference between Selenium 3 and Selenium 4?
answer: Key Differences: | Feature | Selenium 3 | Selenium 4 | |---------|-----------|-----------| | Protocol | JSON Wire Protocol | W3C WebDriver Standard | | Grid | Hub-Node architecture | Unified architecture | | Locators | Basic locators | Relative locators added | | DevTools | Not supported | CDP Support | | Window/Tab | Limited control | Enhanced newWindow() API | Interview Answer: "The main difference is Selenium 4 uses W3C WebDriver protocol instead of JSON Wire Protocol, which means better browser compatibility. It also introduces relative locators (above, below, near), Chrome DevTools Protocol support for performance testing, and improved Grid architecture with Docker support."

question: What are different types of locators in Selenium?
answer: 8 Types of Locators (Priority Order): 1. ID - Fastest, most reliable driver.findElement(By.id("username")) 2. Name - Good for form fields driver.findElement(By.name("email")) 3. Class Name - Use for styled elements driver.findElement(By.className("btn-primary")) 4. CSS Selector - Fast, flexible driver.findElement(By.cssSelector("input[type='submit']")) 5. XPath - Most powerful, can traverse DOM driver.findElement(By.xpath("//button[@id='login']")) 6. Link Text - For anchor tags driver.findElement(By.linkText("Click Here")) 7. Partial Link Text - Partial match driver.findElement(By.partialLinkText("Click")) 8. Tag Name - By HTML tag driver.findElement(By.tagName("input")) Best Practice: Prioritize ID > Name > CSS > XPath

question: Difference between findElement() and findElements()?
answer: Comparison: | Aspect | findElement() | findElements() | |--------|---------------|----------------| | Return Type | WebElement | List | | No Match | NoSuchElementException | Empty List (no exception) | | Usage | Single element | Multiple elements | Code Example: // Single element WebElement button = driver.findElement(By.id("submit")); // Multiple elements List links = driver.findElements(By.tagName("a")); System.out.println("Found " + links.size() + " links"); Interview Tip: "findElement() returns a single WebElement and throws NoSuchElementException if not found. findElements() returns a List that can be empty if no matches, so it's useful when you're not sure if elements exist."

question: What are return types for findElement() and findElements()?
answer: Comparison: | Aspect | findElement() | findElements() | |--------|---------------|----------------| | Return Type | WebElement | List | | No Match | NoSuchElementException | Empty List (no exception) | | Usage | Single element | Multiple elements | Code Example: // Single element WebElement button = driver.findElement(By.id("submit")); // Multiple elements List links = driver.findElements(By.tagName("a")); System.out.println("Found " + links.size() + " links"); Interview Tip: "findElement() returns a single WebElement and throws NoSuchElementException if not found. findElements() returns a List that can be empty if no matches, so it's useful when you're not sure if elements exist."

question: How do you handle frames and iframes?
answer: Handling Frames/iFrames: 3 Ways to Switch to Frame: // 1. By Name or ID driver.switchTo().frame("frameName"); // 2. By Index (0-based) driver.switchTo().frame(0); // 3. By WebElement WebElement frameElement = driver.findElement(By.id("myFrame")); driver.switchTo().frame(frameElement); Switching Back: // Back to parent frame driver.switchTo().parentFrame(); // Back to main page (default content) driver.switchTo().defaultContent(); Interview Answer: "To interact with elements inside a frame, I first switch to that frame using switchTo().frame(). After completing actions, I switch back using defaultContent() for the main page or parentFrame() for nested frames."

question: What are different types of waits in Selenium?
answer: 3 Types of Waits in Selenium: 1. Implicit Wait • Global timeout for all elements • Set once, applies everywhere driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(10)); 2. Explicit Wait • Waits for specific condition • More control, recommended approach WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(10)); WebElement element = wait.until( ExpectedConditions.visibilityOfElementLocated(By.id("result")) ); 3. Fluent Wait • Customizable polling interval • Can ignore specific exceptions Wait wait = new FluentWait<>(driver) .withTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(30)) .pollingEvery(Duration.ofSeconds(2)) .ignoring(NoSuchElementException.class); Interview Answer: "I prefer Explicit Wait because it waits for specific conditions like visibility or clickability, making tests more reliable. Implicit Wait is global but can slow down tests. Fluent Wait is useful when elements have unpredictable load times."

question: How do you handle StaleElementReferenceException?
answer: What is StaleElementReferenceException? Occurs when a WebElement reference is no longer valid because: • Page was refreshed • DOM was updated (AJAX) • Element was removed and re-added Solutions: 1. Re-locate the element: // Instead of storing WebElement WebElement button = driver.findElement(By.id("submit")); // ... some action that refreshes page ... button.click(); // STALE! // Re-locate before use driver.findElement(By.id("submit")).click(); // Works! 2. Use Explicit Wait with refreshed: WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(10)); WebElement element = wait.until( ExpectedConditions.refreshed( ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.id("submit")) ) ); 3. Use try-catch with retry: for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { try { driver.findElement(By.id("submit")).click(); break; } catch (StaleElementReferenceException e) { // Retry } } Interview Answer: "StaleElementReferenceException occurs when the DOM changes after we've located an element. I handle it by re-locating the element, using ExpectedConditions.refreshed(), or implementing a retry mechanism."

question: What is Page Object Model (POM)?
answer: What is POM? A design pattern that creates an object repository for web elements, separating test logic from page-specific code. Key Benefits: • Maintainability - Change locator in one place • Reusability - Methods can be reused across tests • Readability - Tests read like user actions • Reduced Duplication - No repeated findElement calls Structure: public class LoginPage { WebDriver driver; // Locators @FindBy(id = "username") WebElement usernameField; @FindBy(id = "password") WebElement passwordField; @FindBy(id = "login-btn") WebElement loginButton; // Constructor public LoginPage(WebDriver driver) { this.driver = driver; PageFactory.initElements(driver, this); } // Actions public void login(String username, String password) { usernameField.sendKeys(username); passwordField.sendKeys(password); loginButton.click(); } } Interview Tip: "POM helps maintain large test suites by keeping element locators in page classes. If a locator changes, I only update it in one place instead of every test."

question: Advantages and disadvantages of POM?
answer:
Advantages: • Code reusability • Easy maintenance • Readable tests Disadvantages: • Initial setup time • More classes to manage

💡 Interview Tip: Provide a concrete example from your project experience when answering this question.
